## Two points define a line

In HTML, drag the points; in PDF, see the static figure.

::: {.content-visible when-format="html"}
::: {.content-visible when-format="html"}
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/jsxgraph@1.8.0/distrib/jsxgraph.css">
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/jsxgraph@1.8.0/distrib/jsxgraphcore.js"></script>

<div id="jxg" class="jxgbox" style="width:420px;height:320px"></div>
<script>
  const brd = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard('jxg', { boundingbox: [-5,5,5,-5], axis: true });
  const A = brd.create('point', [1,2], { name: 'A' });
  const B = brd.create('point', [-2,-1], { name: 'B' });
  brd.create('line', [A, B]);
</script>
:::

::: {.content-visible when-format="pdf"}
![](figs/line-demo.png){fig-cap="Line through A and B."}
:::

:::



## My First p5.js Sketch

::: {=html}
<!-- p5.js from CDN -->
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/p5@1.9.2/lib/p5.min.js"></script>

<!-- Container for the sketch -->
<div id="p5-container"></div>

<script>
// p5.js sketch as an inline instance mode
new p5(function(p) {
  p.setup = function() {
    let canvas = p.createCanvas(400, 200);
    canvas.parent("p5-container"); // attach to our div
    p.background(220);
  };

  p.draw = function() {
    p.fill(255, 0, 0);
    p.ellipse(p.width/2, p.height/2, 50, 50);
  };
});
</script>
:::
